keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.

The threat was allegedly conveyed through text messages sent on or about October 17, 2025, in which Moynihan wrote messages such as 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.'
Moynihan was sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, and received a full pardon along with over 1,500 other individuals involved in the January 6 Capitol riot.
The arrest raises concerns about the long-term impact of blanket pardons of Capitol rioters, as law enforcement officials report a significant increase in threat assessments against lawmakers.
Capitol Police reported over 14,000 threat assessment cases by the end of 2025, a dramatic rise from previous years, indicating a growing climate of violence and intimidation in U.S. politics.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. The threats were allegedly sent via text messages on or about October 17, 2025, including messages such as 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.' Moynihan, who had previously been sentenced to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, received a full pardon along with over 1,500 others involved in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot. His arrest follows growing concerns about the safety of lawmakers and the consequences of blanket pardons, especially given that the FBI advised New York State Police of the threat and Capitol Police have reported a dramatic spike in threat assessments—over 14,000 by the end of 2025—indicating a broader trend of political violence and intimidation.
